indicators.justification:
In Kazakhstan, the national report on emissions was prepared and published by «Zhasyl Damu», a state-owned company. The report is available on the company's website (1). The last published report is for the year 2017. In addition, the emission dataset is published on the open data portal by governmental agencies. The emission report includes detailed information on the sources of greenhouse gas emissions and uses unique identifiers.

Sources:

1. The national report on emission  
http://zhasyldamu.kz/vidy-deyatelnosti/otchety-i-doklady.html

indicators.justification:
Information on endangered species and ecosystems is available as part of the environmental statistics report (1). 
In addition, endangered species and ecosystems are in the Red Book of Kazakhstan (2). Information in the Red Book assesses the current state of the country's species, but does not allow one to track how they have changed over time. 

Sources:

1. Statistics on endangered species and ecosystem https://stat.gov.kz/search/item/ESTAT099608

2. http://www.redbookkz.info/list.php?taxon=302&lang=ru

3. The National Report on the State of the Environment and the Use of Natural Resources of the Republic of Kazakhstan https://ecogosfond.kz/ltty-bajandama/

indicators.justification:
According to article 23 (subsection 6) of the Environmental Code, the National Report (1) on the State of the Environment and the Use of Natural Resources of the Republic of Kazakhstan should include information on the impacts of climate change, projected impacts of climate change, vulnerability to climate change and measures to adapt to climate change. The national report has been published annually since 2016 on the environmental information portal.
The report includes information on the following economic sectors: land, energy industry, transport and agriculture, and related development of emissions of harmful substances in air, water, soil pollution, waste generated, energy, and natural resources. The national report contains detailed information on the environmental situation in every region and the country as a whole, natural resources and anthropogenic impact on the environment, including the main socially significant environmental problems and the implementation of state policy in the field of environmental protection.

Sources: 
1. The national report  http://ecogosfond.kz/

indicators.justification:
Since 2017, the Government of Kazakhstan has implemented the Code on Subsoil and Subsoil Use with the support of the Extractive Industries Transparency Initiative. The country has progressed and the rules now include a requirement that underground users provide the names of beneficial owners and their level of ownership. Data is available in open data format. In June 2019, the Ministry of Industry and Infrastructure Development disclosed, for the first time, beneficial ownership data in the extractive industries on its website.  
https://www.gov.kz/memleket/entities/miid/documents/details/30278?lang=ru

Sources:

1. Exploration and production licenses list https://www.gov.kz/memleket/entities/miid/documents/details/30278?lang=ru

indicators.justification:
The list of registered legal entities in open data format is available on the Bureau of National Statistics website (1). The register provides all basic information about legal entities. In addition to the company register, there are several other registers, such as the Register of state enterprises and institutions, Entities with state-authorized capital (2), and the Financial Statement Depository for Public Interest Entities (3).The first register contains information about all state-owned companies, and the second register includes financial statements of companies of public interest and NGO databases (4). However, these registers do not provide information in an open data format.

Sources:

1. The Bureau of National Statistics website at https://stat.gov.kz/jur-search/bin.

2. State owned companies register
https://www.gosreestr.kz/en/

3. The Financial Statement Depository for Public Interest Entities (https://dfo.kz/

4. NGO databases https://infonpo.gov.kz/web/guest/otkrytyj-reestr

indicators.justification:
The government created an official COVID-19 info website (1), which contains updates with statistics: total and new cases, deaths per day, mortality and recovery rates, current active cases and vaccination information. 

The COVID-19 vaccination information is published only as news, and the government does not collect it on datasets and does not create databases. General information is available on the website of the Ministry of Health (2). Journalists are forced to collect and summarize information on their own.

Moreover, the government provides only general information on vaccination (number of vaccinated people, region, fully and partially vaccinated). Other information is not available. There is only one example of a dataset (3) as a result of the personal initiative of Madina Baimukhanova, a data analyst from Nur-Sultan. 

Sources:
1. The COVID-19 information website  https://www.coronavirus2020.kz/
2. The website of the Ministry of Health https://www.gov.kz/memleket/entities/dsm/press/news
3. Covid-19 dataset https://datastudio.google.com/u/0/reporting/2ed9408a-1314-47f5-974e-68087b03c824/page/CSCJB?s=pFBdHXZQPRs

indicators.justification:
According to the Open Budget Survey 2019 (1), Kazakhstan's budget transparency score is 58 out of 100. Budget data is available from multiple sources. Budget data is available on governmental websites (2). The development of an online "Open Budgets" portal (3) improved the accessibility of budget data at the budget proposal stage. All governmental agencies at the national and subnational levels publish information about their budget at each stage of the budget process (draft, approved budget, report). In general, consolidated information on the budget is regularly published by the Ministry of Finance (2). There are also examples of initiatives to publish budget data from non-governmental organizations. For example, the project "Open Budget Interactive Map" (4) is aimed at disclosing budget spending at the sub-national level and contains information about the allocated budget funds for public schools, hospitals, etc. The project was initiated by the NGO "Public Foundation for Development of Parliamentarism in Kazakhstan" in collaboration with the Anticorruption agency. 

Sources: 

1. Open Budget Index
https://www.internationalbudget.org/sites/default/files/country-surveys-pdfs/2019/open-budget-survey-kazakhstan-2019-en.pdf

2. The finance ministry website 
https://www.gov.kz/memleket/entities/minfin/activities/448?lang=ru

3. Open budget portal 
https://budget.egov.kz/

4. Open Budget Interactive Map https://publicbudget.kz/ru

5. Open Budget
https://openbudget.kz/class/

responses.response_text: Data is available from government, or because of government actions.
responses.subquestion_text: Is this data available online in any form?
There is structured data available on the executive budget proposal in gross terms, including spending on annual and multi-annual investment projects.
There is structured data available on amended budgets (when applicable) or amendments of the enacted budget.
There is structured data available on the approved or enacted budget in gross terms, including spending on annual and multi-annual investment projects.
There is structured data about government budget execution or spending, in gross terms and on an accrual basis, including spending in annual and multi-annual investment projects.
There is structured data about the government's extrabudgetary funds spending, in gross terms and on an accrual basis.
There is structured data about the government's social security spending, in gross terms and on an accrual basis.
There is structured data about public corporations' spending, in gross terms and on an accrual basis.
Budget entries have administrative classifications to an internationally agreed standard.
Budget entries have economic classifications to an internationally agreed standard.
Budget entries have functional classifications to an internationally agreed standard.
Budget entries have program classifications according to an internationally agreed standard.
Information about individual financial transactions or expenditures is available at the most disaggregated level of the economic classification level.
Data is disaggregated by cross-cutting programs, or issues such as SDGs, climate action, gender budgeting, etc,
The data contains common identifiers to connect budget and budget performance data.
The data contains identifiers that can be used to connect budget data with data on major projects (e.g., infrastructure construction) and procurement processes.
Dataset is available free of charge.
Data is openly licensed.
Data is available in all the country’s official or national languages. If the country has no official or national languages, data is available in the major languages of the country.
There are accessible and open official tools available to help users explore data.

indicators.justification:
The OECD Report (1) of the Fourth Round of Monitoring of the Istanbul Anti-Corruption Action Plan (OECD-ACN-Kazakhstan-Round-4-Monitoring-Report, page 5) recommends "considering to set up the Prosecution Council as a body of prosecutorial self-government, and to introduce mandatory declarations of property, income and expenses of prosecutors and their family members (not connected with their tax liabilities) and make such declarations publicly available". In 2019, in the mass media (2), there was an information campaign from the Anticorruption Agency and the Ministry of Finance on the public availability of income and assets declarations of public servants. However, Kazakhstan has not started disclosing public officials' declarations yet. 

Sources:

1. OECD-ACN-Kazakhstan-Round-4-Monitoring-Report
https://www.oecd.org/corruption/acn/OECD-ACN-Kazakhstan-Round-4-Monitoring-Report-ENG.pdf

2. Discussion in media

https://www.inform.kz/ru/dostup-k-deklaraciyam-o-dohodah-gossluzhaschih-rk-planiruyut-sdelat-otkrytym_a3511633

https://www.kt.kz/rus/state/2020_1377881482.html

According to the national legislation on political parties (1) and elections, the information on campaign and party finance should be published in mass media. However, there is little evidence of the publication of such data. For example, some reports on the use of election funds are available on the Central Election Commission website (2).

indicators.justification:
Data on public discussion of draft legal acts is available on the open legal acts portal (1). The open legal acts portal is a component of the Open Government portal and contains information about draft laws and regulations that are available for public discussion, and it also provides the capability to process feedback through gathering comments and making reports.  

Using advanced search, one can search for the required information and specify a search query by limiting the search by type: status of laws & regulations; government agency that drew it up; category and publication period. According to the information on the NIT JSC website, over 38.000 draft laws and regulations have been published on the portal (2).

Sources:

1. The open legal acts portal https://legalacts.egov.kz/npa/view?id=10551406

https://www.nitec.kz/index.php/en/story/na-portale-otkryityie-npa-realizovan-rasshirennyiy-poisk-i-filtratsiya-dannyih

indicators.justification:
In Kazakhstan, the open data portal was launched in 2013. According to the Open data portal website (1), the data.egov.kz portal contains more than 3 thousand sets of data, which are placed by the following owners of information: central state bodies; local executive bodies of the RK (akimats of regions and the city of Nur-Sultan, Almaty and Shymkent); state-owned organizations.

The Open data portal aims to provide full access to various datasets originating from state agencies. According to the Law on Access to Information, open data is public electronic information resources presented in a machine-readable form and intended for further use, re-publication in an unchanged form. The Open Data portal (data.egov.kz) is one of the components of the Open Government portal (2).

The open government portal is designed to improve government transparency and ensure better collaboration between the government and citizens. The Open government consists of such components as: Open Data, Open RLA, Open Dialogue, Open Budgets, as well as Assessment of the Effectiveness of Government Agencies. All components of the open government portal are actively used by governmental agencies and citizens (3).

Sources: 

1. Open data portal
https://open.egov.kz/

2. About open data portal
https://www.nitec.kz/index.php/en/post/open_gov#:~:text=%D0%92%202014%20%D0%B3%D0%BE%D0%B4%D1%83%20%D0%B1%D1%8B%D0%BB%20%D0%B7%D0%B0%D0%BF%D1%83%D1%89%D0%B5%D0%BD,%D0%BF%D1%80%D0%B0%D0%B2%D0%BE%D0%B2%D1%8B%D1%85%20%D0%B0%D0%BA%D1%82%D0%BE%D0%B2%20%D0%B8%20%D0%BA%D0%BE%D0%BD%D1%86%D0%B5%D0%BF%D1%86%D0%B8%D0%B9%20%D0%B7%D0%B0%D0%BA%D0%BE%D0%BD%D0%BE%D0%BF%D1%80%D0%BE%D0%B5%D0%BA%D1%82%D0%BE%D0%B2.

3. Open government portal 
https://open.egov.kz/

indicators.justification:
Local authorities publish data on the same open data portal as the national state bodies. There are multiple examples at the local level. Since 2012, the following projects have been implemented in Nur-Sultan: Smart schools (19 schools out of 88 connected), Smart street lighting, Smart clinics (2 out of 10 clinics connected). In Almaty, a photo-video recording system for violations has been introduced, and in 2015 the "Onai" electronic ticket system for public transport was launched. A number of projects have been implemented as a part of the Smart cities initiative of the state program Digital Kazakhstan. However, these projects cover only a few big cities and are not yet widely used in other regions. 

Sources:

1. Smart cities
https://m.egov.kz/cms/en/smart-cities?mobile=yes

indicators.justification:
The legal framework for transparency of beneficial ownership in Kazakhstan is obtained through two laws. One is the law on money laundering (1), where there is a definition of a beneficial owner provided. The definition applies to all companies throughout the country. However, the law does not regulate the publication and transparency of the list of beneficial owners. According to Article 77 of the Code on Subsoil Use (2), information on the owners of mining companies should be publicly available. This rule emerged as a result of NGO advocacy on EITI and the government recognized the importance of beneficial ownership transparency. However, the rule has limited capacity. 

In June 2019, the Ministry of Industry and Infrastructure Development disclosed, for the first time, beneficial ownership data on its website (3). The data includes the names of beneficial owners and their level of ownership. However, the data only covers new licenses and is not yet available in open data format.

Sources:

1. The Law on Counteraction of Legitimization (Laundering) of Incomes Received by Illegal Means, and Financing of Terrorism
https://adilet.zan.kz/eng/docs/Z090000191_

2.The code on Subsoil and Subsoil Use in Kazakhstan
https://adilet.zan.kz/eng/docs/K1700000125

3. Exploration and production licenses list
https://www.gov.kz/memleket/entities/miid/documents/details/30278?lang=ru

evidence.title: On Counteraction of Legitimization (Laundering) of Incomes Received by Illegal Means, and Financing of Terrorism

indicators.justification:
Kazakhstan is building a strong legislation framework on the protection of personal data. In 2013, the government adopted the Personal data protection law. The main features of the law is establishing the rules for the collection, storage, processing, and protection of personal data(1). The law establishes: 
1. Key terms: personal data collection, processing, distribution, and de-personalization. 2. Entities involved in the collection and processing of personal data (personal data owners, owners of databases containing personal data, database operators, third parties); 3. instances in which it is permissible to acquire and process personal data without the owner's consent; 4. obligations for de-personalization of data and subsequent destruction of personal information;  In addition, the Law 'On Informatization' adopted in 2015 provides for the measures to prevent illegal access to digital information (2). The Ministry of Digital Development, Innovation, and Aerospace Industry of the Republic of Kazakhstan is the main authority in the area of personal data protection. 

Sources:
1.	On Personal Data and their Protection law (2013)
 https://adilet.zan.kz/eng/docs/Z1300000094
2.	On informatization law (2015)  https://adilet.zan.kz/rus/docs/Z1500000418

indicators.justification:
Kazakhstan has required public officials to declare their assets and incomes since 1996 (1). In 2021, Kazakhstan began the implementation process of a new system of "universal" property and income declarations. Public officials are required to file, in addition to their standard income tax return, a declaration listing the value of their assets and liabilities (2). However, the declarations of public officials remain closed from public access.

indicators.justification:
According to the national legislation on political parties (1) and elections (2), information on campaign and party finance should be published in mass media. To finance their campaigns, parties can use their own funds or accept donations from citizens and organizations. Foreign and anonymous donations as well as contributions from state sources are prohibited. Within five days after the announcement of election results, each contesting party is obliged to submit a campaign finance report to the Central election commission, who should then publish it on its website.

Sources: 

1. The law on Political parties
https://adilet.zan.kz/eng/docs/Z020000344_

indicators.justification:
According to the Law on Access to Information (1), there is a rule on mandatory public discussion of draft legal acts with an obligation of the drafting body to citizens to publicly provide explanations in case of rejection of proposals from citizens. Public discussion on draft legal acts should be organized on the open legal acts portal (2). 

Sources:

1. The Law on access to information
https://adilet.zan.kz/rus/docs/Z1500000401

2. The open legal acts portal https://legalacts.egov.kz/

evidence.title: Rules for posting and public discussion of draft concepts of draft laws and draft regulatory legal acts on the Internet portal of open regulatory legal acts

The framework requires the publication of notice of intent in advance of public consultation processes.
The framework requires the publication of proposed regulations.
The framework requires the timely publication of a full set of public comments generated through public consultation processes.
The framework requires reasoned responses to be published alongside comments.
The framework requires the publication of final regulations and justification.
The framework requires the publication of challenges to laws and regulations that have undergone public consultation processes, as well as their results.
The rules/guidance empower an agency or official to ensure the accurate and timely collection and publication of required data.

indicators.justification:
The national legal framework (1) requires the collection and publication of appeals. RTI/FO is a part of the state's legal statistical reporting (2). The framework covers the entire public sector. The RTI/FO statistics are collected and published by the Committee on the legal statistics and special accounts of the state office of public prosecutor of the Republic of Kazakhstan. The RTI/FO statistics are available on the Committee on legal statistics and special accounts of the state office of public prosecutor of the Republic of Kazakhstan website (3). In addition, the statistical data on RTI/FOI is included in the list of open data posted on the open data portal by the Committee on legal statistics and special accounts (4). 

Sources:

1. ADMINISTRATIVE PROCEDURAL AND PROCESS-RELATED CODE OF THE REPUBLIC OF KAZAKHSTAN https://adilet.zan.kz/eng/docs/K2000000350

2. RTI/FOI collection rules 
https://adilet.zan.kz/rus/docs/V2100022768

3. The Committee on legal statistics and special accounts of the state office of public prosecutor of the Republic of Kazakhstan 
https://www.gov.kz/memleket/entities/pravstat/press/article/details/17348?directionId=6894&lang=en

4. The list of open data the Committee on legal statistics and special accounts
https://adilet.zan.kz/rus/docs/V1800017761

indicators.justification:
The openness of the government procurement portal gives an opportunity for businesses, civil society, and journalists to create different systems and products. These products help identify risky procurements, average prices for goods and services, and, most importantly, they help make the portal and procurements better and more competitive. For example, the open tender project (1) was created by NGO Progress to increase and ease access to public procurement information for journalists. There are multiple examples of how journalists and NGOs use the openness of the public procurement portal for conducting public oversight of public procurement contracts (2). Datanomix, a company that developed the tool based on open data on public procurement in Kazakhstan, which identifies red flags in public procurement (3).

Sources:

1. The Open tender project
https://opentender.kz/

2. Corona Procurement 
https://www.open-contracting.org/2021/03/11/tracking-covid-19-procurement-in-kazakhstan-from-red-flags-to-cancellations/

3. Datanomix
https://www.open-contracting.org/2021/09/20/how-one-data-team-is-rooting-out-procurement-corruption-in-kazakhstan/

evidence.title: NGOs impact on public procurement process

responses.response_text: There is evidence of multiple different uses involving different organisations.
responses.subquestion_text: To what extent is there evidence of this kind of data use?
There is evidence of government procurement data being presented through data-driven dashboards.
There is evidence of government procurement data being used for red flag analysis.
There is evidence that government procurement data is being analyzed to improve access to procurement opportunities for marginalized groups.
There is evidence of government procurement data being analysed to support sustainable / environmental procurement.
There are examples of government using data in these ways.
There are examples of civil society using data in these ways.
There is evidence of private sector using data in this way
At least one of the examples cited appears to make use of open procurement data.
At least one of the examples identified makes use of open beneficial ownership data.
At least one of the examples identified describes using artificial Intelligence or machine learning to process data
There is evidence that these uses have had or are having meaningful positive impacts.
